title: Judges Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who would not allow Samson to go in to his wife into the chamber during the wheat harvest?
questions.correctAnswer: Her father
questions.explanation: Judges 15:1 states that her father would not suffer Samson to go in to his wife into the chamber.

questions.question: What reason did the father give for not letting Samson visit his wife?
options: He thought Samson hated his wife
He wanted Samson to marry the younger sister
questions.correctAnswer: He thought Samson hated his wife
questions.explanation: Judges 15:2 shows the father said he thought Samson had utterly hated his wife, so he gave her to Samson's companion.

questions.question: How many foxes did Samson catch to burn the Philistines' fields?
questions.explanation: According to Judges 15:4, Samson caught three hundred foxes to set fire to the Philistines' crops.

questions.question: What did Samson do with the foxes after catching them?
options: Burnt the fields with firebrands tied to the foxes' tails
Released them in the Philistine city
Killed them and gave meat to the men of Judah
Used them to scare the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt the fields with firebrands tied to the foxes' tails
questions.explanation: Judges 15:5 explains that Samson tied firebrands to the foxes' tails and set fire to the Philistines' corn, vineyards, and olives.

questions.question: Who burned Samson's wife and her father with fire?
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines
questions.explanation: Judges 15:6 states that the Philistines came and burnt Samson's wife and her father with fire.

questions.question: Where did Samson go to dwell after slaying many Philistines?
options: The top of the rock Etam
questions.correctAnswer: The top of the rock Etam
questions.explanation: Judges 15:8 mentions that after slaying many Philistines, Samson dwelt in the top of the rock Etam.

questions.question: What was the reason given by the Philistines for coming up against Judah?
options: To help the men of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: To bind Samson
questions.explanation: Judges 15:10 states the Philistines came to bind Samson and do to him as he had done to them.

questions.question: How many men of Judah went to the top of the rock Etam to speak with Samson?
questions.explanation: Judges 15:11 tells that three thousand men of Judah went to the top of the rock Etam to confront Samson.

questions.question: What did the men of Judah ask Samson to swear before binding him?
options: That they would not kill him
That he would not harm them
That he would fight the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: That they would not kill him
questions.explanation: Judges 15:12 shows Samson asked them to swear they would not fall upon him themselves, meaning they would not kill him.

questions.question: What happened to the cords binding Samson when the Spirit of the LORD came upon him?
options: They became as flax burnt with fire and fell off
They tightened and held him fast
They turned to chains of iron
questions.correctAnswer: They became as flax burnt with fire and fell off
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14 explains the cords on Samson's arms became like flax burnt with fire and his bands loosed from off his hands.

questions.question: What weapon did Samson use to slay a thousand men?
options: A new jawbone of an ass
questions.correctAnswer: A new jawbone of an ass
questions.explanation: Judges 15:15 states Samson found a new jawbone of an ass and used it to slay a thousand men.

questions.question: What name did Samson give to the place where he fought with the jawbone?
questions.correctAnswer: Ramathlehi
questions.explanation: Judges 15:17 says Samson called that place Ramathlehi after he cast away the jawbone.

questions.question: How did God provide water to Samson when he was sore athirst?
options: Water came out from a hollow place in the jawbone
A well appeared in the desert
The men of Judah gave him water
questions.correctAnswer: Water came out from a hollow place in the jawbone
questions.explanation: Judges 15:19 tells God clave a hollow place in the jawbone and water came out for Samson to drink.

questions.question: True or False: Samson judged Israel for twenty years during the time of the Philistines.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 15:20 states that Samson judged Israel in the days of the Philistines for twenty years.

questions.question: True or False: Samson swore to the men of Judah that he would not harm the Philistines.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 15:11-12 shows Samson said he did to the Philistines as they did to him, showing he did not swear not to harm them.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Judges 15:16: 'With the jawbone of an ass, heaps upon heaps, with the jaw of an ass have I slain ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: a thousand men
questions.explanation: Judges 15:16 quotes Samson saying he has slain a thousand men with the jawbone of an ass.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with forgiveness after being wronged by a family member. Based on Judges 15, what biblical truth about dealing with personal offenses can you share?
options: God can use even our anger to accomplish His purposes
We should immediately forgive without addressing the wrong
Avoid confrontation at all costs to keep peace
Retaliate harshly to protect your honor
questions.correctAnswer: God can use even our anger to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Judges 15:3, 7, and 8 show Samson responding to personal offenses with actions that led to God's judgment on the Philistines, illustrating that even difficult emotions can be directed by God for His purposes.

questions.question: How does Judges 15 teach about trusting God in times of trial and danger?
options: God strengthens and delivers those who call on Him
We must rely solely on our own strength
Avoid all risks to prevent suffering
God will always remove trials immediately
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens and delivers those who call on Him
questions.explanation: In Judges 15:14-19, Samson calls on the LORD in thirst and God provides water and strength, demonstrating that trusting God brings deliverance and renewal.

questions.question: What lesson about spiritual discipline and dependence on God can be learned from Samson’s battle at Lehi?
options: The Spirit of the LORD empowers believers for victory
Physical weapons are the only means to succeed
Avoid conflict to maintain spiritual peace
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the LORD empowers believers for victory
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14-15 explains how the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon Samson, enabling him to defeat a thousand men with a jawbone, highlighting dependence on God’s power.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by opposition in their service to God. What encouragement does Judges 15 offer?
options: God equips and strengthens His servants in opposition
Opponents will always overpower God's servants
Avoid all opposition by serving quietly
God expects us to fight alone
questions.correctAnswer: God equips and strengthens His servants in opposition
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14-16 shows that when Samson was bound and surrounded by enemies, the Spirit of the LORD empowered him to overcome, teaching us God’s enablement in trials.

questions.question: How does Judges 15 illustrate the importance of prayer in times of physical need?
options: Samson prayed for water when he was thirsty, and God provided
Prayer is unnecessary when physical needs arise
Only spiritual prayers matter, not physical needs
Physical needs should be met without seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: Samson prayed for water when he was thirsty, and God provided
questions.explanation: Judges 15:18-19 records Samson’s prayer for water and God’s miraculous provision, showing the power of prayer to meet physical needs.

questions.question: What does Judges 15 teach about family relationships and integrity in marriage?
options: Respect and honor marriage commitments despite challenges
It is acceptable to abandon a spouse for convenience
Family disputes should always be ignored
Marriage has no impact on spiritual duties
questions.correctAnswer: Respect and honor marriage commitments despite challenges
questions.explanation: Judges 15:1-2 shows Samson’s desire to visit his wife, despite her father giving her to another, emphasizing the importance of honoring marriage.

questions.question: A believer faces betrayal by close friends. Based on Judges 15, what biblical principle can help them respond?
options: Trust God’s justice even when others fail
Cut off all relationships without reconciliation
Ignore the betrayal and pretend it did not happen
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s justice even when others fail
questions.explanation: Judges 15:11-13 shows Judah’s men binding Samson to hand him over to enemies, yet God delivers Samson, teaching trust in God’s justice.

questions.question: How does Judges 15 encourage humility and contentment after victory?
options: Samson cast away the jawbone after his victory, showing humility
Claim all credit for success without acknowledging God
Never rest after a victory, but press on aggressively
questions.correctAnswer: Samson cast away the jawbone after his victory, showing humility
questions.explanation: Judges 15:17 describes Samson throwing away the jawbone after defeating a thousand men, demonstrating humility and contentment with God's empowerment.

questions.question: True or False: Samson’s actions in Judges 15 show that God approves of revenge motivated by personal anger.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: While Samson’s actions led to deliverance, the text illustrates God’s use of Samson’s anger for His purposes, not that personal revenge is inherently approved (Judges 15:3, 7, 8).

questions.question: True or False: The Spirit of the LORD only comes upon Samson when he is physically strong and free.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14 shows the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon Samson even when he was bound, indicating God’s power is not limited by physical conditions.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After Samson’s victory with the jawbone, he named the place ______.
questions.correctAnswer: Ramathlehi
questions.explanation: Judges 15:17 states Samson called the place Ramathlehi after he cast away the jawbone following his victory.

questions.question: How does Judges 15 teach us about the importance of community accountability in spiritual matters?
options: The men of Judah confronted Samson about his actions
Individuals should act without consulting others
Ignore community concerns to follow personal desires
Accountability is unnecessary when one is spiritually gifted
questions.correctAnswer: The men of Judah confronted Samson about his actions
questions.explanation: Judges 15:10-12 describes how Judah’s men confronted Samson to hold him accountable, teaching the value of community oversight.

questions.question: What does Samson’s experience in Judges 15 teach about perseverance through trials?
options: God sustains us and brings victory despite challenges
Depend only on your own strength to endure
questions.correctAnswer: God sustains us and brings victory despite challenges
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14-16 shows that though Samson was bound and opposed, the Spirit of the LORD empowered him to prevail, encouraging perseverance with God’s help.

questions.question: What biblical truth about gratitude can we learn from Samson’s response after being refreshed with water?
options: He named the place Enhakkore to remember God's provision
He forgot the source of his refreshment
He took credit for the water himself
He ignored the water and continued fighting
questions.correctAnswer: He named the place Enhakkore to remember God's provision
questions.explanation: Judges 15:19 shows Samson called the place Enhakkore (‘the caller’) in gratitude for God’s provision, teaching us to remember and thank God for His blessings.

questions.question: How does Judges 15 exemplify God’s faithfulness in raising up judges to deliver His people?
options: Samson judged Israel for twenty years during Philistine oppression
God abandoned Israel during times of trouble
Israel had no deliverers in difficult times
Judges relied only on their own wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Samson judged Israel for twenty years during Philistine oppression
questions.explanation: Judges 15:20 records Samson judging Israel for twenty years, showing God’s faithfulness in raising deliverers to lead His people.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 15.

questions.question: What was the reason Samson's father-in-law refused him access to his wife’s chamber during the wheat harvest?
options: He thought Samson hated his wife
He wanted Samson to marry the younger sister
questions.correctAnswer: He thought Samson hated his wife
questions.explanation: Her father refused Samson because he thought Samson had utterly hated his wife, as stated in Judges 15:2.

questions.question: In Judges 15, what symbolic act did Samson perform with 300 foxes to take revenge on the Philistines?
options: He tied firebrands to their tails and released them into the crops
He used them to carry messages to the Philistine army
He used them to guard the vineyards
He released them to attack the Philistine villages
questions.correctAnswer: He tied firebrands to their tails and released them into the crops
questions.explanation: Samson caught 300 foxes, tied firebrands between their tails, and set them loose in the Philistine's standing grain and vineyards, burning them (Judges 15:4-5).

questions.question: After Samson’s revenge with the foxes, how did the Philistines respond?
options: They burned Samson’s wife and her father
questions.correctAnswer: They burned Samson’s wife and her father
questions.explanation: The Philistines burned his wife and her father in retaliation, as reported in Judges 15:6.

questions.question: What did Samson declare he would do after the Philistines burned his wife and her father?
options: He would be avenged and then cease
He would seek peace with the Philistines
He would flee to the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: He would be avenged and then cease
questions.explanation: Samson vowed to take revenge on the Philistines and then stop, as stated in Judges 15:7.

questions.question: Where did Samson go to live after slaying the Philistines with great slaughter?
questions.correctAnswer: Top of the rock Etam
questions.explanation: After killing many Philistines, Samson dwelt on the top of the rock Etam (Judges 15:8).

questions.question: What was the reason the men of Judah gave for binding Samson and handing him over to the Philistines?
options: Because the Philistines were rulers over them
Because they wanted to protect Samson
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Philistines were rulers over them
questions.explanation: The men of Judah told Samson that the Philistines ruled over them and that they were coming to bind him (Judges 15:10-11).

questions.question: How did Samson convince the men of Judah not to kill him when they bound him?
options: He made them swear they would not kill him
He threatened them with God's punishment
questions.correctAnswer: He made them swear they would not kill him
questions.explanation: Samson asked them to swear they would not kill him, and they agreed (Judges 15:12-13).

questions.question: What supernatural event occurred when the Philistines shouted against Samson while he was bound?
options: The Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him and the cords fell off
He was strengthened by an angel
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him and the cords fell off
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD came upon Samson, causing the cords binding him to become like burnt flax and fall off (Judges 15:14).

questions.question: What weapon did Samson use to slay a thousand men in Lehi?
options: A sword taken from a Philistine
A spear made by the men of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: The jawbone of an ass
questions.explanation: Samson found a new jawbone of an ass and used it to kill a thousand men (Judges 15:15-16).

questions.question: What name did Samson give to the place where he defeated the Philistines with the jawbone?
questions.correctAnswer: Ramathlehi
questions.explanation: After the battle, Samson named the place Ramathlehi, meaning 'the hill of the jawbone' (Judges 15:17).

questions.question: How did God provide for Samson's thirst after the battle at Ramathlehi?
options: God caused water to come out of a hollow place in the jawbone
God sent rain to quench his thirst
God brought a spring from the rock Etam
questions.correctAnswer: God caused water to come out of a hollow place in the jawbone
questions.explanation: God cleaved a hollow place in the jawbone from which water flowed, and Samson drank and revived (Judges 15:19).

questions.question: What is the significance of the name Enhakkore given by Samson?
options: It means 'spring of the caller' because Samson called on the LORD
It means 'battle site' commemorating the fight
It means 'jawbone place' after the weapon used
It means 'place of deliverance' from the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: It means 'spring of the caller' because Samson called on the LORD
questions.explanation: Enhakkore means 'spring of the caller,' named because Samson called on God for water (Judges 15:19).

questions.question: How long did Samson judge Israel during the time of the Philistines?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: Samson judged Israel for twenty years during the days of the Philistines (Judges 15:20).

questions.question: True or False: Samson's act of tying firebrands to foxes and burning the Philistine fields prefigures the prophetic imagery of destructive judgment found in later biblical literature.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samson’s destructive act with firebrands and foxes symbolizes divine judgment and foreshadows prophetic imagery of destruction by fire in the Hebrew Bible, aligning with themes of retributive justice (Judges 15:4-5).

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in the sequence where Samson is bound by men of Judah, then empowered by the Spirit of the LORD to break free and defeat the Philistines?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiastic structure
questions.explanation: The narrative shows a chiastic structure: men of Judah bind Samson (A), Spirit empowers him to break free (B), Samson defeats Philistines (B'), and the place is named (A'). This highlights divine empowerment and reversal of human restraint (Judges 15:12-17).

theological.title: Judges Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial reason Samson visited his wife during the wheat harvest?
options: To go into the chamber with her
questions.correctAnswer: To go into the chamber with her
questions.explanation: Judges 15:1 states Samson said, 'I will go in to my wife into the chamber.' This shows his intent was intimate fellowship, consistent with biblical teaching on marriage (Genesis 2:24, Song of Solomon 1:4, 1 Corinthians 7:3-5).

questions.question: Why did the father of Samson's wife refuse to let Samson visit her?
questions.correctAnswer: He thought Samson hated her
questions.explanation: Judges 15:2 says her father thought Samson hated his wife, so he gave her to Samson's companion. This reflects human misunderstanding and broken relationships due to sin (Genesis 4:8, Proverbs 17:14, Matthew 18:15).

questions.question: How did Samson respond to the situation with his wife and her father?
options: He said he would be more blameless than the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: He said he would be more blameless than the Philistines
questions.explanation: Judges 15:3 records Samson's declaration that he would be more blameless than the Philistines, showing his sense of moral justification despite conflict, reflecting human pride and justification (Romans 3:10, Isaiah 64:6, 1 John 1:8).

questions.question: What method did Samson use to retaliate against the Philistines’ fields?
options: He caught 300 foxes and set their tails on fire
He attacked their cities with swords
questions.correctAnswer: He caught 300 foxes and set their tails on fire
questions.explanation: Judges 15:4-5 describes Samson catching foxes, tying firebrands to their tails, and setting the Philistine crops ablaze. This act of judgment mirrors biblical themes of divine retribution and covenant justice (Exodus 22:6, Psalm 37:28, Nahum 1:2).

questions.question: What was the Philistines’ response to the destruction of their crops?
options: They burned Samson’s wife and her father
questions.correctAnswer: They burned Samson’s wife and her father
questions.explanation: Judges 15:6 notes the Philistines burned Samson’s wife and her father, reflecting the tragic consequences of sin and escalating cycles of violence (Genesis 4:23-24, Judges 21:25, Romans 1:28-32).

questions.question: What did Samson declare after the Philistines burned his wife and her father?
options: He would be avenged and then cease
questions.correctAnswer: He would be avenged and then cease
questions.explanation: Judges 15:7 quotes Samson, 'Though ye have done this, yet will I be avenged of you, and after that I will cease,' illustrating themes of divine vengeance and human limitation (Romans 12:19, Deuteronomy 32:35, Hebrews 10:30).

questions.question: Where did Samson dwell after slaying many Philistines in battle?
questions.correctAnswer: Top of the rock Etam
questions.explanation: Judges 15:8 records Samson dwelling at the top of the rock Etam. This place served as a refuge, symbolizing God’s provision of refuge in times of conflict (Psalm 18:2, Psalm 91:2, Isaiah 33:16).

questions.question: Why did the men of Judah seek to bind Samson?
options: To deliver him to the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: To deliver him to the Philistines
questions.explanation: Judges 15:10-13 shows Judah’s men intending to bind Samson and hand him over to the Philistines, revealing human fear and failure to fully trust God’s purposes (Exodus 32:25-29, John 11:47-53, Acts 7:54-60).

questions.question: What happened when the men of Judah bound Samson with new cords?
options: The cords fell off as if burnt by fire
He escaped by cutting the cords
questions.correctAnswer: The cords fell off as if burnt by fire
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14 describes the Spirit of the LORD coming mightily upon Samson, causing the cords to become like burnt flax and fall off. This highlights the empowering presence of the Holy Spirit in deliverance (Judges 14:6, Acts 1:8, 2 Timothy 1:7).

questions.question: What weapon did Samson use to slay a thousand men?
options: A new jawbone of an ass
questions.correctAnswer: A new jawbone of an ass
questions.explanation: Judges 15:15-16 states Samson used the jawbone of an ass to slay a thousand men, showing God’s power working through unlikely means, echoing themes of divine strength in human weakness (1 Samuel 17:40-50, 2 Corinthians 12:9, Hebrews 11:34).

questions.question: What name did Samson give to the place where he killed the Philistines with the jawbone?
questions.correctAnswer: Ramathlehi
questions.explanation: Judges 15:17 records Samson naming the place Ramathlehi, meaning 'the hill of the jawbone,' commemorating God’s deliverance, aligning with biblical practice of memorializing God’s acts (Genesis 28:19, Exodus 17:15, 1 Samuel 7:12).

questions.question: How did God provide for Samson when he was thirsty after the battle?
options: Water came out of a hollow in the jawbone
A spring appeared in the desert
A well was dug by his men
questions.correctAnswer: Water came out of a hollow in the jawbone
questions.explanation: Judges 15:19 shows God cleaving a hollow place in the jawbone and water coming out, reviving Samson. This act reflects God’s sustaining grace and provision (Exodus 17:6, John 4:14, Isaiah 55:1).

questions.question: What does Samson’s thirst and God’s provision of water symbolize in a Christological context?
options: Spiritual thirst and Christ as the living water
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual thirst and Christ as the living water
questions.explanation: Samson’s thirst and God’s provision (Judges 15:18-19) can be seen as a type of spiritual thirst quenched by God’s grace, prefiguring Christ’s offer of living water (John 4:13-14, Revelation 22:17, Isaiah 55:1).

questions.question: How long did Samson judge Israel during the days of the Philistines?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: Judges 15:20 states Samson judged Israel for twenty years, showing God’s ongoing deliverance through imperfect human instruments, paralleling other judges like Deborah and Gideon (Judges 4:4, Judges 8:28, Acts 13:20).

questions.question: What attribute of God is revealed by the Spirit coming mightily upon Samson?
options: God’s silence in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God’s empowering presence for deliverance
questions.explanation: Judges 15:14 shows the Spirit of the LORD coming mightily on Samson, revealing God’s attribute of empowering His servants to accomplish His purposes despite human weakness (Exodus 31:3, Isaiah 11:2, Romans 15:13).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the cycle of sin, judgment, and deliverance in Samson’s story in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy amidst human failure
questions.explanation: Judges 15 shows sin, conflict, and God raising deliverers like Samson, emphasizing divine mercy and grace despite human sinfulness (Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 103:8-14, Romans 5:8).
